Question No. 1 / Question ID 703002 | Shift - 1
The number 68132 ‚Äì 31932 is divisible by
1. both 362 and 1000
2. 362 but not 1000
3. 1000 but not 362
4. neither 362 nor 1000

Answer: 1
In the question, look for the unit digit number and the power.
For example, the powers of 9 operate as follows:
91 = 9,
92 = 81,
93 = 729, and so on.
Hence, the power cycle of 9 also contains only 2 numbers 9 & 1, which appear in case of odd and even powers
respectively. While that for 1 raised to any power will result in unit place being 1. When 1 is subtracted with 1 it
results in a 0 at unit place, making the number divisible by both 362 and 1000.
Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 2 / Question ID 703001 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following graphs represents the displacement vs time relation for the motion of a ball
thrown upward and returning toward the ground, remaining in air for 10 seconds? (Ignore air resistance.)

Answer: 4
Displacement is a vector quantity and depends on the direction. If an object returns to its original place the net
displacement will be zero. But as the ball gains height it will tend to deaccelerate thus taking more time to
cover the same distance and thus the plot between displacement versus time cannot be sharp as seen in option
A. Thus the answer is option D.
Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 3 / Question ID 703016 | Shift - 1
Vehicle number plates have two letters out of the 26 letters of the English alphabet followed by four decimal
digits. How many different number plates are possible if repetition of letters and digits is allowed?
1. 26 √ó 25 √ó 10 √ó 9 √ó 8 √ó 7
2. 26 √ó 26 √ó 10 √ó 10 √ó 10 √ó 10
3. (26 √ó 25 √ó 24 √ó 23 √ó 10 √ó 9) / (4 √ó 3 √ó 2 √ó 2)
4. 26 √ó 25 √ó 24 √ó 23 √ó 10 √ó 9

Answer: 2
The vehicle number is consisting of total 2+4 = 6 figures. If the repetition is allowed, then at the first two places
the total combinations are 26 x 26. While at the next 4 places are numbers with total of 10 choices. Therefore,
the total possible combinations are 26 x 26 √ó 10 √ó 10 √ó 10 √ó 10.

Question No. 4 / Question ID 703005 | Shift - 1
In a grid puzzle, each row and column in the 9 √ó 9 grid, as well as each 3 √ó 3 subgrid shown with heavy
borders, must contain all the digits 1 ‚Äì 9.

In the given partially fil led grid, the digit in the square marked "?" is
1. 3

2. 9

3. 8

4. 7

Answer: 2
As per the rule in each row, column and subgrid must contain all the digits 1 ‚Äì 9 once. If we look at nearby
subgrids and the options, 9 cannot occur at any other place than at question mark.

Question No. 5 / Question ID 703003 | Shift - 1
In an examination 3 medals were awarded for each of 5 subjects. If three candidates won exactly four
medals each, and no candidate won Just one medal, the total number of medal winners
1. was exactly 4
2. was exactly 5
3. could be either 5 or 6
4. was exactly 6

Answer: 1
three candidates won exactly four medals each, i.e. 3 √ó 4 = 12
Total number of medals = 3 √ó 5 = 15
Therefore, remaining medals 15-12 = 3
and, with no candidate winning just one medal, answer cannot be 5 or 6 candidates.

1. 11 min
2. 16 min
3. 22 min
4. 44 min

Answer: 2

Question No. 7 / Question ID 703013 | Shift - 1
The sum of squares of four integers
1. can never be divisible by 13
2. can never be divisible by 15
3. can be divisible by 17
4. can never be divisible by 19

Answer: 3
if we look at all the options, there is only one statement which gives liberty to state may or may not be. Stating
always a number being indivisible will need thorough validation and is not possible logically.

Question No. 8 / Question ID 703010 | Shift - 1
If ab : 5, bc = 7 and ca = 11, which of the following identities is valid?
1. ?
2. ?
3. ?
4. ?

Answer: 1
if we take ab/bc = 5/7 i.e. a/c = 5/7 ‚áí 7a = 5c
ab/ac = 5/11 i.e. b/c = 5/11 ‚áí 11b = 5c
i.e., 7a = 5c = 11b

Question No. 9 / Question ID 703006 | Shift - 1
In the given triangle ABC, a square is drawn as shown. Given,

‚à†BAC = 90¬∞, BC = a, BD = x and EC = y ;

which of the following is the area of the square?
1. (a ‚Äì x)y

2. (a ‚Äì y)x

3. (a ‚Äì x)(a ‚Äì y )

4. xy

G

F

Answer: 4
Given: DEFG is a square and ‚à†BAC=90¬∞.
In ŒîAFG and ŒîDBG
‚à†GAF = ‚à†BDG [90¬∞]
‚à†AGF = ‚à†DBG [corresponding angles because GF|| BC and AB is the transversal]
ŒîAFG‚âàŒîDBG [by AA Similarity Criterion] ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶(1)
In ŒîAGF & ŒîEFC
‚à†AFG = ‚à†CEF [90¬∞]
‚à†AFG = ‚à†ECF [corresponding angles because GF|| BC and AC is the transversal]
ŒîAGF‚âàŒîEFC [by AA Similarity Criterion] ‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶(2)
From equation 1 and 2.
ŒîDBG‚âàŒîEFC
BD/EF=DG/EC
BD/DE = DE/EC [ DEFG is a square]
DE2=BD√óEC. (BD = x and EC = y, Given)
Hence the area of the Square is xy unit

Question No. 10 / Question ID 703019 | Shift - 1
A circular disk of unit radius rolls along a straight line from P to Q.

Which of the following figures shows the orientation of the disk at Q?
1. A
2. B
3. C
4. D

Answer: 3
the perimeter of the circle is 2ùúãùúãùëüùëü with r=1, that is in one role the distance covered will be 2ùúãùúã that means in 4
complete rotations the distance covered will be 8ùúãùúã and the last ùúãùúã distance will require half the turning of disk,
that satisfies option C as answer.

deducting 1 mark. Unattempted questions fetch nothing. If a candidate with a few wrong answers secures 44
marks, how many questions were attempted?
1. 15
2. 16
3. 17
4. 18

Answer: 2
The student must attempt 16 question including 4 wrong answers to score 44 marks

Question No. 14 / Question ID 703011 | Shift - 1
The shape of a country on a map is approximated by a kite with diagonals of length 300 km each. The
minimum possible length of its boundary will be closest to
1. 1696 km

2. 1131 km

3. 848 km

4. 600 km

Answer: 3
A kite with diagonals of same length is a Square
Therefore the diagonals of the country (Kite) bisect each other perpendicularly.
In ‚àÜAOB
B
AO = 150km (half of diagonal AC)
BO = 150km (half of diagonal BD)
Using Pythagoras theorem we can find AB
(AB)2 = (AO)2 + (BO)2
(AB)2 = (150)2 + (150)2
AB = 212.13 (All the other sides should be Same as the shape of the county is square).
The boundary of the country = the perimeter of the square
4 x side = 848.52

A

o

D

C

8,3,4,9,3,5,9,5,9,9,9,4,5,9,5,6,3,3,5,7,2,3,9,9,8,9,3,9,1,9,4

2. 4
3. 5
4. 6

Question No. 16 / Question ID 703012 | Shift - 1
A rectangular paper of sides in the ratio 3:4 is folded in half across the longer side. The process is repeated
several times. After how many foldings will the ratio of the sides be 3:4? (Ignore the finite thickness of the
paper.)
1. Never
2. Every second fold
3. Every third fold
4. Every fifth fold

Answer: 2 Paper is folded in half across the longer side.
Original ratio = ¬æ = 0.75
¬æÔÉ†3/2ÔÉ†1.5/2 = 0.75
We can see the ratio repeats after every 2nd fold.

Question No. 17 / Question ID 703008 | Shift - 1
Six years ago. the ages of three persons were in ratio o 3:5:8. If the sum of their ages 8 years from now
would be 122, what are their present ages (in years)?
1. 15, 25, 40

2. 21, 31, 46

3. 15, 25, 30

4. 21, 26, 37

Answer: 2
Let the present ages of
P: 3x + 6
Y: 5x + 6
Q: 8x + 6
After 8 years,
P + Y = Q = (3x + 6 + 8) + (5x + 6 + 8) + (8x + 6 + 8) = 122
‚áí 16x + 42 = 122
‚áí 16x = 80
‚áíX=5
Therefore the present age of P,Y and Q is 21,31 and 46 respectively
Pathfinder Academy

Question No. 18 / Question ID 703014 | Shift - 1
Four students Adil, Billy, Ramesh and Diana joined a college in 1991 , 1992, 1993 and 11994 but not
necessarily in that order. Each student joined one of the four departments, viz. Physics, Chemistry,
Mathematics and Biology. No two students joined the same department. One of those who joined the college
before 1993 joined Chemistry. No one joined the college after Ramesh. Diana joined Physics. Adil joined one
year after Diana but didn't join Chemistry. Who Joined the college in the year 1993?
1. Adil

2. Billy

3. Ramesh

4. Diana

Question No. 19 / Question ID 703004 | Shift - 1
Suppose each of my brothers has the same number of children as I have sisters, each of the sister having
the same number of children as I have brothers. If my siblings have a total of 12 children, none of them an
only child, the number of my siblings is
1. 3
2. 5
3. 6
4. 7

Answer: 2
Here we have to find the minimum number of siblings so that the sum of 12 children can be reached
irrespective of how many brothers and sisters. Also none of the sibling can have a single child, that means that
there are more than 1 brother and sister. If we take answer as 5 considering 3 of one sex and 2 of other, we
have:
Number of children = 3 x 2 + 2 x 3 = 12

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 20 / Question ID 703017 | Shift - 1
The population of a species (Y) changes with the month (x) as shown in the graph. Which of the following
equations best describes the population curve?
1. y = 3x + 3.2
2. y = 0.96 (x ‚Äì 4)
3. y = 0.3x2 + x + 3.6
4. y = 0.3x + 3.6

Answer: 4
If we see the plot, all the points on the plot can be summarized through a single straight line passing nearby
these points.
Slope = ‚àÜùëåùëå/ ‚àÜùëãùëã = (5.2-4.9)/(7-6) approx. values = 0.3
Intercept on the Y-axis = 3.6
Therefore, the expression y = mx + c is satisfied by option 4.

Question No. 1 / Question ID 703064 | Shift - 1
During animal cell culture , which one of the following cell types would NOT require trypsin for passaging?
1 Epithelial cells
2. Hematopoietic cells
3. Fibroblasts
4. Myoblasts

Answer 2
Among the options provided, hematopoietic cells would generally NOT require trypsin for passaging during
animal cell culture. Hematopoietic cells, such as blood cells (e.g., lymphocytes, monocytes), are usually not
detached using trypsin.

Question No. 3 / Question ID 703056 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following four plant families has the largest number of species?
1. Brassicaceae
2. Cucurbitaceae
3. Cactaceae
4. Rosaceae

Answer 4
Rosaceae is a large family of flowering plants that includes many economically important fruit crops such as
apples, pears, cherries, strawberries, and roses. It is one of the most diverse and widespread plant families,
comprising a significant number of species.

Question No. 6 / Question ID 703052 | Shift - 1
In a mutagenesis experiment, the following pedigree was obtained. All progeny had the same phenotype.
The mutation is most likely to have occurred
1. during maturation of the egg cell.
2. in the maternal somatic cell.
3. in the mother in the precursor to all germ cells.
4. in the embryo during development.

Answer 3
The pedigree information suggests that all progeny have the same phenotype, which indicates that the
mutation is likely to have occurred in the germ cell lineage. This would affect all cells derived from that germ
cell, leading to a consistent phenotype in all offspring.

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 7 / Question ID 703061 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following geological events in the Cretaceous had a massive impact on the climate and
biodiversity of India?
1. Origin of Tibetan plateau
2. Deccan Trap volcanic activity
3. Formation of Lonar Lake
4. Origin of Himalayan mountains

Answer 2

Question No. 8 / Question ID 703050 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following options contains only those types of mapping populations that are characterized
by 'true-breeding' individuals?
1. RlLs and F2 populations
2. F2 populations and BC1F2
2. Doubled haploid populations and BC1F2
4. Doubled haploid populations and RlLs

Answer 4
Doubled Haploid (DH) populations and Recombinant Inbred Lines (RILs) are two types of populations used in
genetics and plant breeding research. DH populations are created by doubling the chromosome number in a
haploid cell, resulting in an individual that is homozygous at all loci. RILs are generated through several
generations of selfing and sibling mating. The lines are derived from the same initial cross, and each line is
typically homozygous but may differ from each other due to recombination events during the generations.

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 9 / Question ID 703062 | Shift - 1
Monogamy in sexually reproducing animals ;is seemingly paradoxical given that males must maximize their
number of matings for higher fitness. Yet, many birds are known to be monogamous. Which one of the
following statements represents a scenario where monogamy in birds ls LEAST likely to evolve?
1. Poor quality of habitat wherein resources are hard to find
2. Males guard females after mating with them
3. Mates are scattered and hard to find
4. Offspring do not require elaborate parental care

Answer 4
Monogamy in birds often evolves when there is a need for parental care, and both parents contribute to raising
offspring. If offspring do not require elaborate parental care, there may be less pressure for both parents to stay
together.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 2

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 10 / Question ID 703036 | Shift - 1
Kaposi's sarcoma is caused by
1. Epstein-Barr virus
2. HIV and HHV-8
3. HTLV type1
4. HPV

Answer 2
Kaposi's sarcoma is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), also known as Kaposi's sarcoma-associated
herpesvirus. This virus is associated with the development of Kaposi's sarcoma, a type of cancer that usually
manifests as skin lesions. Kaposi's sarcoma is often seen in individuals with weakened immune systems, such as
those with HIV/AIDS.

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 13 / Question ID 703044 | Shift - 1
In the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana, methionine is a precursor amino acid in the biosynthesis of
1 . Alkaloids
2. Glucosinolates
3. Phenolics
4. Terpenoids

Answer 2
Glucosinolates are a group of sulfur-containing compounds that play a role in plant defense against herbivores
and pathogens. Methionine is involved in the biosynthetic pathway leading to the production of glucosinolates.

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 14 / Question ID 703023 | Shift - 1
One strand of a palindromic dsDNA is composed of 5' - CCGCGGCGG - 3'. Which one of the following forms
of nucleic acid structures will be adopted in water if sense and antisense strands are mixed in equal
proportion followed by annealing?
1. A-form of double-stranded nucleic acid
2. B-form of double-stranded nucleic acid
3. Z-form of double-stranded nucleic acid
4. Both will remain as single strands

Answer 2
The B-form is the most common and stable structure for DNA in water, and it is characterized
by a right-handed helix with a defined major and minor groove.

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 15 / Question ID 703068 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following techniques allows the study of all three types of interactions namely,
protein:protein, protein:DNA, and protein:RNA?
1. Differential display
2. Phage display
3. ChIP assay
4. Southwestern blotting

Answer 2
Phage display is a powerful molecular biology technique used for the study of protein-protein interactions,
protein folding, and identification of peptides or proteins with specific functions. The method involves the use
of bacteriophages (viruses that infect bacteria) to display foreign peptides or proteins on their surface.
Source: Biophysics & Molecular Biology ‚Äì Tools and Techniques

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 16 / Question ID 703049 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following is true for Genome-wide association study (GWAS)?
1. There is a need to make controlled crosses or work with human families with known parent-offspring relationship.
2. All alleles in the population are assayed at the same time.
3. Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) cannot be used for such studies.
4. Knowledge about candidate genes is essential.

Answer 2
A Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS) is a research approach that involves scanning the entire genome of
individuals to identify genetic variants associated with a particular trait, disease, or phenotype. GWAS is a
powerful tool for investigating the genetic basis of complex traits and diseases.

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 17 / Question ID 703040 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following floral homeotic genes is transcribed in all four whorls during flower development?
1. AP1
2. AP2
3. AP3/PI
4. AG

Answer 2 Incorrect*
In the wild-type flower of Arabidopsis, whorl 1 is determined to be sepals by the product of class A genes (APETALA1 and
APETALA2) alone; whorl 2 is determined as petals by the combined actions of class A genes and class B genes (APETALA3
and PISTILLATA); whorl 3 is determined as stamens by the combined actions of class B genes and class C genes
(AGAMOUS) and whorl 4 is determined as carpels by the action of class C gene alone. Development of the ABC model
contributed greatly to our understanding of floral development. The model has recently been expanded to include five
gene classes (A, B, C, D, E) and is therefore known as the ABCDE model of flower development. The class E genes are
required for the functioning of A-, B- and C- class genes. In Arabidopsis, the class E genes include SEPALLATA 1‚Äì4 (SEP 1‚Äì4)
genes.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 2

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 18 / Question ID 703070 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following statistical methods compares the means of the populations?
1. t-test
2. Chi-square test
3. Analysis of Variance
4. Principal Component Analysis

Answer 1

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 19 / Question ID 703039 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following statements is correct for dosage compensation in human?
1. X-chromosome inactivation in female occurs in a zygote immediately after fertilization.
2. X-chromosome inactivation is non-random, in some individuals maternal X is inactivated while in others
paternal X-chromosome is inactivated.
3. Y-chromosome of males is seen as Barr body.
4. The body of female is a mosaic of cells, some having paternal X- and others having maternal X-inactivated.

Answer 4
In humans, females have two X chromosomes, while males have one X and one Y chromosome. This difference
in the number of X chromosomes could potentially lead to an imbalance in gene expression if not compensated
for. The process of dosage compensation in humans primarily involves inactivating one of the two X
chromosomes in females. This inactivation is known as X-chromosome inactivation. In each cell of a female's
body, one of the two X chromosomes is randomly inactivated during early embryonic development.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 2

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 21 / Question ID 703038 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following statements regarding the developmental potential of cells in embryo is INCORRECT?

Question No. 22 / Question ID 703034 | Shift - 1
Phosphatidylinositol (Pl) is unusual among membrane lipids because it can undergo reversible
phosphorylation at multiple sites on the inositoI head to generate a variety of phosphorylated Pl lipids called
phosphoinositides. In a cell signaling event, the enzyme that directly converts Pl(4,5)P2 to Pl(3,4,5)P3 is:
I. PI 3-Kinase
2. PLCŒ≤
3. PTEN
4. Protein Kinase B

Answer 1
The activation of PI3K leads to the phosphorylation of phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) to generate
phosphatidylinositol 3,4,5-trisphosphate (PIP3). PIP3 serves as a second messenger that activates downstream
signaling pathways,

Question No. 23 / Question ID 703058 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following options lists landmasses that were au a part of the ancient Gondwana supercontinent?
1. Australia, New Zealand, and North America
2. Africa, Europe, India, New Zealand, and South America
3. Africa, Europe, India, Madagascar, and North America
4. Africa, Australia, Antarctica, India, Madagascar, and South America

Answer 4
The Gondwana supercontinent was a vast landmass that existed from the Late Precambrian to the Jurassic
period. It was formed by the assembly of several continental blocks, primarily in the Southern Hemisphere. The
remnants of the Gondwanan landmasses are now part of several continents. For example, parts of South
America, Africa, Antarctica, Australia, the Indian subcontinent, and Madagascar were once part of Gondwana.

Question No. 26 / Question ID 703069 | Shift - 1
What type of electromagnetic radiation is used in biomolecular NMR spectroscopy?
1. Radio waves
2. Beta emissions
3. X-ray waves
4. Microwaves

Answer 1
In biomolecular Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, electromagnetic radiation in the radio wave
is utilized. The technique relies on the principles of nuclear magnetic resonance, which involves the interaction
of nuclei with an external magnetic field and radio wave.

Question No. 28 / Question ID 703033 | Shift - 1
Choose the INCORRECT statement:
1. Tetanospasmin is associated with Tetanus
2. Tetanospasmin is a neurotoxin
3. Tetanospasmin facilitates the release of gamma-aminobutyric acid at synapses
4. Immunization with toxoids is used for the prevention of tetanus.

Answer 3
Tetanospasmin is a neurotoxin produced by the bacterium Clostridium tetani, which is responsible for causing
tetanus. Tetanospasmin primarily affects inhibitory neurotransmission. It blocks the release of neurotransmitters,
including GABA and glycine, from inhibitory interneurons.

Question No. 31 / Question ID 703063 | Shift - 1
Sometimes similar traits or characteristics evolve in two distinct lineages independently, such as venoms in
scorpions and snakes. This process can be described as:
1. Convergent evolution
2. Microevolution
3. Macroevolution
4. Divergent evolution

Answer 1
Convergent evolution is a biological phenomenon in which different organisms independently evolve similar
traits or characteristics in response to similar environmental challenges or selection pressures.

Question No. 33 / Question ID 703025 | Shift - 1
Fifteen spontaneous Ara- mutants of E.coli that were not able to utilize arabinose as a sole carbon source ln
minimal synthetic medium at 42¬∞C were isolated. However, interestingly all these mutants were able to use
arabinose as the sole carbon source at 30¬∞C. Based on the above information, which one of the following
options represents the most likely type of the mutations?
1. Deletions
2¬∑ Inversions
3. Frameshift mutations
4. Missense mutations

Answer 4 incorrect*
It should be conditional mutations. The conditional mutations are genetic mutations in organisms that result in
a phenotype that is dependent on certain environmental conditions or factors. These mutations exhibit their
effects only under specific circumstances, allowing researchers to control the expression or activity of the
mutated gene.

Question No. 38 / Question ID 703027 | Shift - 1
Which cell cycle phase is typically the shortest in mammalian cells?
1. G0 phase
2. G1 phase
3. G2 phase
4. Mitosis

Answer 4
Mitosis is the phase of the cell cycle where the cell divides its nucleus into two identical daughter nuclei. It
consists of several stages, including prophase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase. While the duration of each
stage can vary, mitosis is generally shorter compared to the other phases of the cell cycle.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 1

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 39 / Question ID 703032 | Shift - 1
RNA polymerase is an enzyme that transcribes DNA sequences into RNA. Which one of the following is NOT
a property of the RNA polymerase?
1. RNA polymerases initiate RNA synthesis without primers that provide a free 3‚ÄôOH group
2. RNA polymerases have high fidelity due to the action of proof-reading endonuclease activity
3. In eukaryotes, RNA that encodes ribosomal proteins is transcribed by RNA polymerase II
4. RNA polymerases initiate RNA synthesis from defined regions of DNA

Answer 2
RNA polymerases are enzymes responsible for synthesizing RNA from a DNA template during transcription.
Unlike DNA polymerases, most RNA polymerases lack intrinsic proofreading activities. This results in a higher
error rate during RNA synthesis.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 2

Question No. 41 / Question ID 703028 | Shift - 1
Porins, which are normally present on the outer mitochondrial membrane, reach their destination by
1. direct synthesis of porins on mitochondria membrane by the mitochondrial protein synthesis machinery.
2. synthesis on the ER and transport via vesicles to the mitochondria.
3. synthesis in the cytosol, import by TOM complex and insertion from the inter-mitochondrial membrane space.
4. synthesis in the cytosol, import by TIM complex and insertion in the membrane.

Answer 3
Porins are indeed present in the outer mitochondrial membrane, and their synthesis typically occurs in the
cytosol. The TOM complex, located in the outer mitochondrial membrane, facilitates the import of precursor
proteins into the mitochondria. After entering the inter-membrane space of mitochondria, the precursor
proteins are translocated across the outer mitochondrial membrane.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 1

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 42 / Question ID 703051 | Shift - 1
In a family, the father has an X-linked mutation causing a late-onset lethal disorder and the mother is not a
carrier. Based on the above information, which one of the following statements about the children the couple
may have is correct?
1. There is a 50% chance that the son will show the disorder.
2. No children will show the disorder.
3. The probability that the parents have a daughter carrying a mutant allele is 25%.
4 . All daughters will carry the mutant allele.

Answer 4
Since the mother is not a carrier, the only way a daughter can carry the mutant allele is if she inherits the X
chromosome with the mutation from the father. Hence, all daughters will carry the mutant allele.

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

2. fertilizin, hyaluronidase
3. lysin, hyaluronic acid

Sperm carry enzymes such as lysin and hyaluronidase that play crucial roles in the process of fertilization. These
enzymes help the sperm penetrate the layers surrounding the egg, allowing for successful fertilization

Question No. 44 / Question ID 703022 | Shift - 1
The pH of endocytic vesicles is 5.2, and the pH of gastric juice is 2.0. The endocytic vesicle has a [H+] that is
1. 15.85 times lower than that of gastric juice.
2. 0.1585 times lower than that of gastric juice.
3. 158.5 times lower than that of gastric juice.
4. 1585 times lower than that of gastric juice.

Answer 4
The difference in the log value (i.e. pH) is greater than three units, which means that the original concentration of
proton differs by more than 1000 times between the organelles.

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 45 / Question ID 703030 | Shift - 1
P-bodies are discrete cytoplasmic collections of RNAs and proteins that are involved in:
1. Deadenylation, decapping and mRNA degradation
2. Deadenylation and mRNA degradation only
3. Deadenylation and decapping only
4. Decapping and mRNA degradation only

Answer 1
P-bodies (Processing bodies) are complexes of translationally repressed mRNAs associated with a large number
of proteins involved in translation repression, RNA interference, mRNA surveillance and mRNA degradation.
Translation initiation factors and ribosomal proteins are generally excluded from P-bodies with the exception of
eIF4E in mammalian P-bodies. P-bodies are dynamic complexes whose assembly is dependent on, and
proportional to, the pool of nontranslating mRNA.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 2

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

1. Catecholamines
2. Insulin
3. T3 and T4
4. Steroids

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 47 / Question ID 703065 | Shift - 1
In the production of alcohol by fermentation, in the absence of oxygen, yeasts convert glucose to pyruvate
and pyruvate to ethanol. Fermentation promotes glycolysis by
1. Converting acetaldehyde to alcohol to prevent feed-back inhibition
2. Generating NAOH for mitochondrial ATP generation
3. Preventing toxicity of acetaldehyde
4. Generating NAD+ for glycolysis

Answer 4
During glycolysis, glucose is metabolized to pyruvate, and NAD+ is reduced to NADH. In the absence of oxygen, if
NADH is not regenerated, glycolysis cannot continue because there will be a shortage of NAD+. The
fermentation process, which involves the conversion of pyruvate to ethanol, allows NADH to be oxidized back to
NAD+, ensuring that glycolysis can proceed, and the cells can continue to generate ATP through anaerobic
respiration
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 1

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 48 / Question ID 703046 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following is involved in the pinching-off of the neck of invaginating coated pit to form
endocytotic vesicle at the pre-synaptic terminal?
1. Synaptojanin
2. AP2
3. Clathrin
4. Dynamin

Answer 4
Dynamin is essential for the fission of vesicles from the cell membrane during endocytosis. It forms a helical
structure around the neck of the vesicle and, through its GTPase activity, constricts and cleaves the vesicle from
the membrane.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 1

Question No. 49 / Question ID 703031 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following functions is NOT facilitated by a tmRNA?
1. Addition of a stop codon at the 3' end of a defective and/or truncated mRNA.
2. Addition of a proteolysis-inducing tag at carboxyl terminus of unfinished polypeptide.
3. Release of defective and/or truncated mRNA from the ribosome.
4. Recycling of the stalled ribosomes.

Answer 1
tmRNA (transfer-messenger RNA) is a unique RNA molecule found in bacteria and some other microorganisms. It
plays a crucial role in rescuing stalled ribosomes during translation and in the degradation of aberrant proteins.

Question No. 50 / Question ID 703054 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following terms describes the biological classification system based on common
ancestry?
1. Linnean taxonomy
2. Binomial nomenclature
3. Phylogenetic classification
4. Rank based classification

Answer 3
Phylogenetic classification is a method of organizing and categorizing living organisms based on their
evolutionary relationships. This approach groups organisms together based on shared ancestry and common
evolutionary traits. The resulting classification system reflects the evolutionary history of organisms, with
closely related species grouped into the same taxonomic categories.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 1

Question No. 1 / Question ID 703131 | Shift - 1
The graph given below is based on the optimal foraging theory. If the Y axis represents "Cumulative
Resource Intake" following the law of diminishing returns, what do T and T' stand for?
1. T: Patch residence time, T': Travel time to reach patch
2. T: Search time to find prey T': Handling time for a prey
3. T: Travel time to reach patch, T': Patch residence time
4. T: Handling time for a prey, T': Search time to find prey

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 2 / Question ID 703088 | Shift - 1
The table below represents some protein modifications in Column X and their functions in Column Y.
Column X
Column Y
Protein modification
Function
a. Palmitoylation
i. Protein degradation
b. polySUMOylation
ii. Membrane anchoring
c. Glycosylphosphatidylinositol
iii. Lysosomal targeting
d. Mannose-6-phosphate
iv. Protein folding
Which one of the following options represents all correct matches between Column X and Column Y?
1. a-ii, b-i, c-iv, d-iii
2. a-i, b-iv, c-ii, d-iii
3. a-ii, b-i, c-ii, d-iii
4. a-iv, b-iv, c-ii, d-i
Answer 3
A palmitic acid (16-carbon, saturated fatty acid) molecule attaches to a Cys residue close to the N- or C-terminus via a thioester
linkage (palmitoylation). A glycosylphosphatidylinositol molecule (GPI) attaches to the C-terminal amino acid via an amide linkage.
PolySUMOylation refers to the attachment of multiple Small Ubiquitin-like Modifier (SUMO) proteins to a target protein.
SUMOylation is a post-translational modification where SUMO proteins are covalently attached to specific lysine residues on target
proteins, typically altering their function, localization, or interactions with other molecules.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 1

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 3 / Question ID 703080 | Shift - 1
The statements below attempt to describe a few characteristics of Alu repeats found in the human genome
A. Alu elements are a class of short interspersed elements (SINEs).
B. SINEs are autonomous transposons.
C. Alu repeat originated from cDNA copies of 7SL RNA.
D. Alu repeats have a relatively high AT content.
E. They are preferentially located in the gene-poor G chromosome bands.
Which one of the following options shows combination of all correct statements?
1. A, B and E
2. B, C and D
3. A and C only
4. C and E only
Answer 3
The most common SINES in human genome is Alu elements. Alu elements frequently contain a site for the
restriction enzyme AluI and consequently are called Alu elements. These about 300-bp sequences are scattered
throughout the human genome, constituting ~10 percent of the total DNA. A related transposable element, B1,
is found in the mouse genome. Both of these transposable DNA sequences are thought to have evolved from
the gene for 7SL scRNA, a non coding RNA involved in the movement of the polypeptide in the organelles.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 2

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 4 / Question ID 703142 | Shift - 1
Following are marker enzymes that would be used to identify correct subcellular fractions.

Which one of the following options correctly pairs the enzymes With the subcellular fractions?
1. A-i, B-ii, C-iii, D-iv
2. A-iv, B-iii, C-i, D-ii
3. A-iii, B-i, C-ii, D-iv
4. A-ii, B-iv, C-iii, D-i

Answer 3

Question No. 5 / Question ID 703135 | Shift - 1
The table below lists phylogenetic reconstruction methods and the description of these methods, which
includes both algorithmic and optimality-based methods or criteria.
Method (Column X)
A. Maximum parsimony
B. Minimum evolution
C. Bayesian
D. Neighbour Joining

Description (Column Y)
i. Tree length, that is sum of branch lengths, often estimated by least
squares.
ii. Minimum number of changes, minimized over ancestral states
iii. Cluster algorithms to arrive at a single tree.
iv. Posterior probability, calculated by integrating it over branch lengths
and substitution parameters

Select the option that best matches the tree reconstruction method (Column X) with its correct description in
Column Y.
1. A-ii, B-i, C-iv, D-iii
2. A-iv, B-iii, C-i, D-ii
3. A-i, B-ii, C-iv, D-iii
4. A-i, B-iii, C-ii, D-iv
Answer 1

Question No. 6 / Question ID 703090 | Shift - 1
The cAMP-PKA-GREB pathway regulates many important biological processes, from hormone synthesis to
inducing long-term memory ln the brain. The following statements describe the effects of mutations in the
components of the pathway on gene transcription by GREB.
A. Loss of function mutation in a cAMP binding site of the PKA regulatory subunit leads to the inactivation of
gene expression.
B. Activating mutation in the GTP-binding domain of the a subunit of Gs leads to the activation of gene
expression.
C. Inactivating mutation that prevents the regulatory subunit of PKA to bind the catalytic subunit leads to
the activation of gene expression.
D. Inactivating mutation in the PKA phosphorylatlon site of GREB leads to the activation of gene expression.
Which one of the following statements is INCORRECT?
1. Only A
2. A and D
3. Only D
4. B and D
Answer 3
An inactivating mutation in the PKA phosphorylation site of GREB leads to the activation of gene expression,
which is incorrect. Inactivation of the phosphorylation site would usually result in a loss of the ability to be
phosphorylated, and phosphorylation is often associated with activation rather than inactivation.
Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 7 / Question ID 703134 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following Newick trees represents the correct relationship between apes?
1. ((((Orangutan, Gibbons), Gorillas), Chimpanzees), Humans)
2. ((((Humans, Chimpanzees), Gorillas), Orangutan), Gibbons)
3. ((((Humans, Gorillas), Chimpanzees), Gibbons), Orangutan)
4. ((((Humans, Chimpanzees), Gibbons), Orangutan), Gorillas)

Answer 2
Newick format is a way of representing hierarchical tree structures, particularly phylogenetic trees in biology. It
is a simple and widely used format for describing the relationships between different species or other entities.
The Newick format represents trees as nested sets of parentheses and commas.

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 8 / Question ID 703112 | Shift - 1
Given below are statements about the Kallmann syndrome.
A. It is a condition of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.
B. There is a loss of sense of smell in such individuals.
C. This syndrome is most common in women.
D. It happens due to mutation of the KALIG1 gene on X-chromosome that codes for an adhesion molecule
necessary for the normal development of the gustatory nerve.
Which one of the following options has the combination of all correct statements?
1. A and D
2. B and C
3. C and D
4. A and B
Answer 4
Kallmann syndrome (a congenital hypogonadotropic hypogonadism) combines an impaired sense of
smell with a hormonal disorder that delays or prevents puberty. The hormonal disorder is due to
underdevelopment of specific neurons, or nerves, in the brain that signal the hypothalamus.
Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 9 / Question ID 703099 | Shift - 1
Mechanism of primary sex determination is best known in Drosophila and mammals. Given below are
statements in regard of sex determination ln these two model systems.
A. In Drosophila, if sry gene product is present, it may block beta-catenin signaling and along with SF1,
activate the sox9 gene.
B. In mammals, an alternate splicing of Sxl transcript that removes a stop codon and allows formation of a
functional protein, is responsible for initiating the female sex determination.
C. A trans-splicing event in Tra transcript results in formation of functional Tra protein in Drosophila.
D. XO individuals in Drosophila are males while, XXY individuals are females.
Which of the above statements are correct?
1. A, B and C
2. D only
3. C and D
4. B only
Answer 2
In Drosophila, the Y-chromosome is not involved in determining sex. A ratio of X-chromosomes to autosomal
sets determines the sex of Drosophila. A normal diploid male contains 2 sets of autosomes and XYchromosomes. Similarly, a normal diploid female has 2 sets of autosomes and two X-chromosomes.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 2

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 10 / Question ID 703122 | Shift - 1
Given below are species concepts (Column X) and their descriptions (Column Y):

Which one of the following options represents all the correct matches?
1. A-ii, B-iii, C-i, D-iv
2. A-i, B-ii, C-iii, D-iv
3. A-iii, B-ii, C-i, D-iv

4. A-iv, B-iii, C-i, D-ii

Answer 1
A phylogenetic concept suggests that species should be considered to be monophyletic or exclusive groups. An evolutionary
species is a group of organisms that shares an ancestor; a lineage that maintains its integrity with respect to other lineages
through both time and space.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 2

Question No. 11 / Question ID 703121 | Shift - 1
Selected human diseases and their vectors are listed below:
Column X
Disease
A. Chikungunya
B. Lyme disease
C. Lymphatic filariasis
D. Schistosomiasis

Column Y
Vector
I. Aedes mosquito
ii. Anopheles mosquito
iii. Aquatic snails
iv. Ticks

Which one of the following options represents the correct match between column X and column Y?
1. A-ii, B-iii, C-iv, D-i
2. A-iii, B-iv, C-i, D-ii
3. A-i, B-ii, C-iii, D-iv
4. A-i, B-iv, C-ii, D-iii
Answer 4
Schistosomiasis is an acute and chronic parasitic disease caused by blood flukes (trematode worms) of the
genus Schistosoma. Lyme disease is an illness caused by borrelia bacteria. Humans usually get Lyme disease
from the bite of a tick carrying the bacteria.

Question No. 18 / Question ID 703078 | Shift - 1
Iron (Fe) is taken up by cells via receptor-mediated endocytosis utilizing transferrin and transferrin receptor.
In a cell fine with a mutation in the transferrin receptor that is unable to interact with transferrin at pH (4-6),
which one of the following steps will be first affected in this pathway?
1. Binding of transferrin to iron in plasma.
2. Association of iron bound transferrin with transferrin receptor on the plasma membrane.

Question No. 19 / Question ID 703100 | Shift - 1
The following statements describe the developmental processes during different modes of reproduction in angiosperms:
A. In double fertilization, one sperm fuses with the egg and other with the central cell to form the zygote and endosperm, respectively.
B. In sporophytic apomixis, a diploid cell gives rise to the next generation thereby maintaining the maternal genotype.
C. In gametophytic apomixis, a reduced egg cell forms apomictic embryo through parthenogenesis.
D. In pseudogamy, the functional endosperm is formed without fertilization.
Which one of the following represents the combinations of CORRECT statements?
1. A and B
2. B and C
3. B and D
4. C and D

Answer 1
Sporophytic apomixis is also referred to as adventitious embryony. The embryo develops directly from
diploid somatic (sporophytic) cells within the ovule. There is no embryo sac formation. Embryos are
formed directly from unreduced cells of the nucellus, or inner integument. In gametophytic apomixis,
functional female gametophyte i.e., embryo sac, develops without meiosis (apomeiosis). Hence, the
embryo sac has the same number of chromosomes as the mother plant. The embryo sac may arise
either from an archesporial cell (megaspore mother cell) or from non-archesporial cell of the nucellus.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 2

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 20 / Question ID 703141 | Shift - 1
Figure A represents the sites for Ncol (N) in a binary vector pCSIR2023. The vector is 16500 bp in size. Figure B represents
the fragments observed when the vector is either digested with Ncol (IN) or double digested with Hindlll and Ncol (H+N). The

2. There are three sites of Hindlll, one of which is located in the ~ 1.6Kb fragment generated by Ncol digestion.

4. There are four sites of HindIll, one of which is at 2015 position.

Question No. 21 / Question ID 703125 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following statements about change in temperature with elevation is correct?
1. Adiabatic cooling of air due to in creasing elevation leads to a drop of temperature by ~ 10¬∞c for every 1,000 min elevation,
irrespective of water vapor or cloud formation.
2. Adiabatic cooling of air due to increasing elevation leads to a drop of temperature by ~ 10¬∞C for every 1,000 m in elevation,
as long as no water vapor or cloud formation occurs.
3. A vertical ascent of 1km from the Earth surface produces a temperature change roughly equivalent to that brought about
by an increase in latitude of 1,000 km.
4. A vertical ascent of 600 m from the Earth surface produces a temperature change roughly equivalent to that brought about
by an increase in latitude of 100 km.

Answer 2
The statement is a generalization of the adiabatic cooling of air as it rises in the atmosphere. The lapse rate, which is the rate
at which temperature decreases with an increase in altitude, is approximately 10¬∞C per 1,000 meters for dry adiabatic cooling.

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 22 / Question ID 703081 | Shift - 1
In C. elegans, PAR proteins segregate at the cell cortex in the zygote to establish cell polarity. This is
dependent on the regulation of the cortical actin cytoskeleton by RhoA. An investigator sought to directly
inhibit actin polymerization to analyze the impact of this inhibition on PAR protein localization. Which one of
the following chemicals would be the most suitable?
1. Taxol
2. Colchicine
3. Latrunculin
4. LY294002

Answer 3
Latrunculin is a natural product and a potent actin polymerization inhibitor. It is derived from marine sponges,
particularly the genus Latrunculia. Latrunculin disrupts the organization of the actin cytoskeleton in eukaryotic cells by
preventing the polymerization of actin monomers into actin filaments.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 1

The amino acid sequence of tetrapeptides (P, Q, R) is shown below.

i.

Calculate the net charge on the above tetrapeptides at pH 7.0

tetrapeptide will elute last? Choose the correct answer given below.
1. i) P, -2 ; Q, +1 ; R, +2 and ii) R
2. i) P, -3; Q, +2 ; R, +3 and ii) Q
3. i) P, -1 ; Q, +1 ; R, +1 and ii) p

Question No. 27 / Question ID 703137 | Shift - 1
Unknown antigens can be detected or measured by a sandwich ELISA whereas Elispot assays measure the
number of cells capable of secreting particular molecules such as cytokines which is considered as
antigens. Which of the following is true for both assays?
1. Reaction products in both the assays are soluble.
2. Reaction products in both the assays are insoluble.
3. Reaction products in sandwich ELISA are insoluble whereas those in Elispot assays are soluble.
4. Reaction products in sandwich ELISA are soluble whereas those in Elispot assays are insoluble.

Answer 4
In a sandwich ELISA, antigens (proteins) are detected and quantified. In an Elispot assay, the number of cells
producing a specific molecule (e.g., cytokines) is measured. In a sandwich ELISA, the reaction products are
typically soluble. In an Elispot assay, the reaction products are insoluble.

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

By expressing the EGF-like ligand LIN-3, the C. elegans anchor cell (AC) directly triggers vulval

Question No. 29 / Question ID 703111 | Shift - 1
The following proposed statements describe some aspects of thermoregulation.
A. The basal metabolic rate is rapidly adjusted in the thermoneutral zone to maintain temperature homeostasis.
B. The homeotherms who have the ability to hibernate ,. do not maintain normal physiological temperature range
during hibernation.
C. The thermoregulation is not regulated by hypothalamus.
D. Warm-blooded animals require more food compared to cold-blooded animals of the same size and weight.
Which one of the following options represents combinations of all correct statements?
1. A, B and C
2. A, B and D
3. B and D only
4. A and B only

Pathfinder Academy

Answer 3
Thermoregulation is indeed regulated by the hypothalamus, a region of the brain that plays a crucial role in
maintaining homeostasis, including the regulation of body temperature. The basal metabolic rate (BMR) is
not rapidly adjusted within the thermoneutral zone to maintain temperature homeostasis. Instead, the
BMR is a measure of the energy expenditure required to maintain basic physiological functions at rest in a
thermoneutral environment.
Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 30 / Question ID 703071 | Shift - 1
The central rod domain of keratin protein is 300 amino acids in length. What is the approximate length (in √Ö)
of the rod domain if the peptide consists of
i) distorted Œ±-helix
ii) true Œ±-helix
iii) anti-parallel Œ≤-sheet
1. (i) 425 √Ö; (ii) 450 √Ö; (iii) 1041 √Ö
2. (i) 450 √Ö; (ii) 450 √Ö; (iii) 840 √Ö
3. (i) 425 √Ö; (ii) 425 √Ö; (iii) 1004 √Ö
4. (i) 340 √Ö; (ii) 425 √Ö; (iii) 104 √Ö

Answer 1
True Œ±-helix : 1.5 √ó 300 = 450
Anti-parallel Œ≤-sheet : ~3.5 √ó 300 = ~1054

Question No. 32 / Question ID 703074 | Shift - 1
In a mammalian cell undergoing active glycolysis, what would be the effect of a sudden increase in the
concentration of metabolites, AMP, citrate, ATP, and glucose-6-phosphate?
A. Increased ATP inhibits glycolysis.
B. Increased AMP stimulates glycolysis.
C. Increased citrate and glucose-6-phosphate stimulate glycolysis.
D. Increased AMP and citrate inhibits glycolysis.
Which one of the following represents the combination of all correct statements?
1. C and D
2. B and D
3. A and B
4. A and C

Answer 3
High ATP levels indicate an abundance of energy, and this can lead to feedback inhibition of
glycolysis. Therefore, statement A is correct. High levels of AMP, which is an indicator of low
energy status, activate glycolysis. Therefore, statement B is also correct.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 1

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

2. A- North and Central America, B -Africa , C - Asia, D - South America

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 34 / Question ID 703079 | Shift - 1
In yeast, temperature-sensitive mutants of cell cycle regulators, cdc2 (the key cyclin-dependent kinase), cdc13
(required for telomeric DNA replication), and cdc13 rad9 (that carries an additional mutation in the DNA damage
sensor) were isolated. When grown in non-permissive temperature for a few hours, different phenotypes were
observed in these mutants. Choose the option that correctly describes the most likely phenotype for all of these
mutants.
1. The cdc2 mutants will arrest in G1/S, cdc13 in M and cdc13 rad9 in S-phase.
2. The cdc2 mutants will arrest after a few divisions in G1 , cdc13 in M and cdc13 rad9 in S-phase.
3. The cdc2 mutants will arrest in G1/S, G2 and M, cdc13 in G2 and cdc13 rad9 will continue to divide for a few
generations.
4. The cdc2 mutants will arrest in G1/S, G2 and M, cdc13 in G1 and M and cdc13 rad9 in all phases of the cell cycle.

Answer 3
The cdc2 mutants exhibit a broad cell cycle arrest phenotype, cdc13 mutants specifically arrest in G2, and cdc13
rad9 mutants exhibit a unique phenotype of continued division for a limited number of generations, possibly
due to the influence of the additional DNA damage sensor mutation.

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 35 / Question ID 703106 | Shift - 1
Given below are the list of plant hormones (Column X) and their biosynthesis precursors (Column Y) .

Which one of the following options represents the correct match between column X and Y?
1. A - i; B - ii; C - iii; D - iv
2. A- iii; B - i; C- iv; D - ii
3. A- iii; B- ii; C- iv; D - i
4. A- iv; B - iii;. C- ii ; D - i

Question No. 37 / Question ID 703107 | Shift - 1
The structure and process of formation of different antigens in blood ABO system are given in the following statements:
A. Galactose is added to the terminal of H-antigen by a transferase expressed in individuals with type A blood.
B. The B antigen is formed by a transferase expressed in individuals with type B blood which adds a terminal Nacetylgalactosamine to H-antigen.
C. The H-antigen is formed by fucose transferase that adds a terminal fucose to its precursor.
D. The H-antigen is the precursor of both the A- and B- antigens and it is the blood group antigen ln persons of type O blood.
Which one of the following options represents the correct combination of statements?
1. A and B

2. Band C

3. C and D

4. A and D

Answer 3
A and B antigens derive from H antigen. During the formation of A and B antigens, H antigen (encoded by H gene) acts as a
precursor oligosaccharide. An enzyme fucosyltransferase is responsible for the synthesis of H antigen, that adds fucose to a
precursor oligosaccharide. Gene encoding this enzyme is located on the 19th chromosome (19q13.3) in humans and has two
alternative (allelic) forms‚ÄîH and h. Individuals with genotypes HH or Hh produce H antigen whereas genotype hh do not produce
H antigen. Because the H antigen is an essential precursor to the A and B antigens, individual with genotype hh cannot produce A
and B antigens.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 1

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 38 / Question ID 703091 | Shift - 1
Extracellular matrix comprises of various proteins and polysaccharides that assemble into an organized
meshwork. This associates with the cells that produce them. Given below are a few statements regarding
different components of the matrix ..
A. Collagen is the major protein of the extracellular matrix and is a long, and triple-stranded helical structure.
B. Hyaluronan which is produced in large quantities during wound healing is a type of glycosaminoglycan
(GAG) that contains sulfated sugar and is covalently linked to the core protein.
C. Syndecans are plasma membrane proteoglycans that interact with the actin cytoskeleton and signaling
molecules of the cell cortex.
D. Decorin is a small proteoglycan secreted by fibroblasts and contains 1- 10 GAG chains.
Which one of the following options represents INCORRECT statements?
1. C and D only

2. B, C and D

3. A and B

4. B only

Answer 4
Hyaluronan is a non-sulfated glycosaminoglycan composed of repeating disaccharide units. It is not covalently linked to a core
protein and is not sulfated.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 1

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 39 / Question ID 703119 | Shift - 1
Consider a highly diverse community of Closely related species of lizards which has evolved in a short
period of time and that occupies different ecological niches in peninsular India. What type of speciation
process can explain the above pattern?
1. Non-ecological speciation
2. Adaptive radiation
3. Allopatric speciation
4. Parapatric speciation

Answer 2
In the described case, the closely related lizard species have evolved to occupy different ecological niches in
peninsular India. This pattern is consistent with the concept of adaptive radiation, where the ancestral species
undergoes rapid speciation to adapt to diverse environmental conditions and ecological roles.

Question No. 42 / Question ID 703095 | Shift - 1
Several extracellular mechanisms lead to intracellular changes to regulate stem cell behavior during
development. Based on this, Which one of the following statements is NOT true?
1. Structural and adhesion factors in the extracellular matrix support cellular architecture of the stem cell
niche.
2. Different patterns of chromatin accessibility influence gene expression related to stem cell behavior.
3. Partitioning of cytoplasmic determinants distributes factors determining cell fate evenly into daughter
cells during asymmetric division.
4. Secreted proteins from surrounding cell ls by autocrine, paracrine or juxtacrine mechanisms often
maintain stem cells in an uncommitted state .

Answer 3
Partitioning of cytoplasmic determinants distributes factors determining cell fate evenly into daughter cells
during asymmetric division. It is not true. Asymmetric division involves the uneven distribution of cytoplasmic
determinants, leading to daughter cells with different cell fates. This process contributes to cellular diversity.

Question No. 47 / Question ID 703129 | Shift - 1
Based on theoretical concepts of mating systems in plants, pollen : ovule ratios are likely to be most
skewed in which one of the following cases?
1. Entomophilous dioecious species
2. Entomophilous bisexual species
3. Anemophilous bisexual species
4. Anemophilous dioecious species

Answer 4
Anemophilous dioecious species are plants that are dioecious, meaning individual plants are either male or
female, and their pollination occurs through the action of the wind. The term "anemophilous" refers to the
method of pollination where pollen is dispersed by the wind.

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 48 / Question ID 703133 | Shift - 1
Given below are statements related to different types of natural selection models.
A. Directional selection changes the average value of a trait.
B. Stabilizing selection increases variation in a trait.
C. Disruptive selection reduces variation in a trait.
D. Balancing selection maintains variation in a trait.
Select the correct option that represents the combinations of statements that are NOT true about natural selection.
1. A and B
2. B and C
3. C and D
4. A and C
Answer 2
Stabilizing selection favors individuals with intermediate values of a trait, reducing variation around the mean. It does not increase
variation. Disruptive selection favors individuals at both extremes of a trait, leading to an increase in variation. It promotes the divergence
of traits within a population.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 2

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 49 / Question ID 703101 | Shift - 1
Given below are few statements regarding the light absorption by chlorophyll pigment in a green leaf.
A. The absorption of a photon by a pigment molecule converts it from its lower state to an excited state.
B. Internal conversions or relaxations of pigments convert higher excited states to the lowest excited state,
with a concomitant loss of energy as heat.
C. The light reemitted from the lowest excited state of chlorophyll molecule is fluorescence.
D. Red light absorption by chlorophyll molecule results into higher excitation state relative to the blue light
absorption.
Which one of the following combinations is correct?
1. A, B and C

2. A, B and D

3. B, C and D

4. A, C and D

Answer 1
Red light absorption by chlorophyll molecule results into higher excitation state relative to the blue light absorption. The statement is
not accurate. In photosynthetic pigments, including chlorophyll, the absorption of light energy leads to the excitation of electrons to
higher energy states. Blue light has a shorter wavelength and higher energy compared to red light.

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 50 / Question ID 703083 | Shift - 1
Following statements were made about mRNA splicing:
A. Involvement of a cis-acting branchpoint site present near 3' end of each exon is essential for splicing.
B. In the first step of splicing reaction, 2‚Äô-OH of the conserved U at the branch-site acts as a nucleophile to attack
the phosphoryl group of the conserved G in the 5' splice site.
C. The newly liberated intron adapts shape of a lariat due to joining of the 5' end of the intron to the branchpoint.
D. During the splicing process , there is no net gain in the number of chemical bonds.
E. Prp22 (a DEAD-box helicase) is required for stripping the spliced mRNA from the spliceosome.
Which one of the following options shows combination of all correct statements?
1. B, C, D
2. C, D, E
3. A and E only
4. B and D only

Answer 2
Involvement of a cis-acting branchpoint site present near 3' end of each exon is essential for splicing: It is not true. The
branchpoint site is not near the 3' end of each exon; rather, it is located within the intron. The branchpoint is typically
an adenosine residue in the intron sequence, and it is essential for the splicing reaction. In the first step of splicing
reaction, 2‚Äô-OH of the conserved U at the branch-site acts as a nucleophile to attack the phosphoryl group of the
conserved G in the 5' splice site: It is not true. In the splicing reaction, it is the 2'-OH group of the branchpoint
adenosine (A) that acts as a nucleophile, not a U. The nucleophile attacks the 5' splice site, leading to the formation of a
lariat intermediate and the exon being ligated to the intron.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 2

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 51 / Question ID 703097 | Shift - 1
Given below are statements about development in different model organisms.
A. Xenopus egg has yolk and hence undergoes meroblastic cleavage.
B. Embryonically transcribed beta-catenin in the blastomeres of sea urchin embryos regulates the autonomous
specification of micromeres.
C. The sodium pump activity in the trophoblast helps in the formation of blastocoel of a mammalian blastocyst.
D. Prevention of tubal pregnancy is one of the major functions of zona pellucida in humans.
Which combination of the statements is true?
1. A and B
2. A and C
3. B and D
4. C and D

Answer 4
Amphibians (Xenopus laevis), undergo a holoblastic cleavage pattern generating
blastomeres containing an unequal amount of yolk with increasing volume towards the vegetal pole.
In sea urchin embryos, beta-catenin is not embryonically transcribed.

Question No. 53 / Question ID 703118 | Shift - 1
A new strain of bacteria was created by introducing an artificial operon, to allow bacterial cells to grow in
the presence of iron. The Fe++ operon consisted of genes that made the cells capable of tolerating
increased iron. For efficient functioning of this operon, the following desirable features were considered.
Which one of the following can be used to develop this operon?
1. A repressor protein, which is active when bound to Fe++
2 . An activator protein, which is active when not bound to Fe++
3. A repressor protein, which is inactive when bound to Fe++
4 . A repressor protein, which is active constitutively

Answer 3
A repressor protein, which is inactive when bound to Fe++. This implies that the repressor is inactive in the presence of
iron, allowing transcription of the operon. This could be a desirable feature for promoting bacterial growth in the
presence of iron.

Question No. 55 / Question ID 703072 | Shift - 1
Which one of the following nucleic acids with same concentrations in water, will form a stable stem-loop
structure upon annealing by heating and flash cooling on ice?
1. 5' - GGCUUAUUUUCUUCGG -3'
2 . 5' - CCGAACUUUUAUUCGG -3'
3. 5' - AUGCCAUUUUCGGCUU -3'
4. 5‚Äô - AGAGCGUUUUAUUCGG -3'

Answer 2
To form a stable stem-loop structure, the sequence should have regions where complementary base pairing can
occur. The most likely sequences to form a stable stem-loop structure are those that can pair with themselves in
an antiparallel manner.

Question No. 57 / Question ID 703093 | Shift - 1
Apoptosis refers to programmed cell death that is triggered by specialized intracellular proteases called caspases. The intrinsic
pathway of apoptosis
A. depends on the activation of Fas domain by the Fas ligand, which activates the DISC.
B. is regulated by the Bcl2 family of proteins.
C. consists of a key regulatory protein Apaf1 which is a water-soluble component of the electron transport chain.
D. recruits procaspase 9 into the apoptosome, and once activated, caspase 9 cleaves and activates downstream executioner
caspases.
Which of the following combinations represents alI correct statements?
1. A, B and D

2. B, C and D

3. C and D only

4. B and D only

Answer 4
Depends on the activation of Fas domain by the Fas ligand, which activates the DISC: This statement refers to the extrinsic pathway of
apoptosis, not the intrinsic pathway. The intrinsic pathway is mitochondrial-mediated and involves the release of cytochrome C. Apaf1
(apoptotic protease-activating factor 1) is a cytoplasmic protein, and it is not a component of the electron transport chain.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 1

Question No. 65 / Question ID 703104 | Shift - 1
Apoplast phloem loading is determined by the cellular location and transport function of the membranebound proteins. Following are certain statements regarding these proteins.
A. SWEETs are the sugar transporter proteins and are capable of transporting only sucrose and not glucose.
B. Double mutants of Arabidopsis SWEET11 and SWEET12 results in carbohydrate accumulation in the
source leaves and slower export of the photoassimilates.
C. H+-symport mechanism loads sucrose or polyols into Sieve Element (SE)/Companion Cell (CC) complexes.
D. Several clades of sucrose/H+ symporters (SUTs or SUCs) are localized to plasma membranes of minor vein
SE/CCs and participate in apoplastic loading.
Which one of the following combinations ls correct?
1. A, B and C

2. A, B and D

3. B, C and D

4. A, C and D

Answer 3
In the apoplastic loading, sucrose synthesized in the photosynthetic cells is first released outside the cell (i.e., into the
apoplast). How this release occurs was a mystery until the discovery of efflux proteins SWEETs (Sugar Will Eventually be
Exported Transporters). SWEETs (function as uniporters) efflux sucrose and other hexoses down their
concentration gradient across the plasma membrane.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 2

Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 66 / Question ID 703077 | Shift - 1
P. aeruginosa makes a blue-green pigment called pyocyanin. To understand the pyocyanin biosynthetic pathway,

‚Äì is pyocyanin negative; + pyocyanin positive
Based on this data, can you predict how many genes are responsible for the pyocyanin production?
1. One

2. Two

3. Five

4. Six

Answer 3
Mutant 1 and 6 belongs to same complementation group. So, total number of genes responsible for the
pyrocyanin are five.

is most likely to be true?
1. Both groups of mice will have very similar levels of antibody against LPS as it is a thymus- independent
antigen.
2. No immune response will be generated in both groups of mice as they lack thymus.
3. Only Group A mice will have antibodies as T-independent antigens are dependent on T-cell activation.
4 . Only Group B mice will have antibodies, because in group A mice, the presence of T cells will interfere with
the production of antibodies against T-independent antigen.

Answer 1

Question No. 75 / Question ID 703102 | Shift - 1
Photorespiration or C2 cycle takes place in three distinct organelles in the plant cells. Following are certain
statements related to the C2 cycle.
A. Reduced ferredoxin and ATP are required for photorespiration and assimilation of resulting NH3.
B. Photosynthetic electron transport provides energy rich ATP and NAPDH for photorespiration.
C. Glutamate is translocated from chloroplast to peroxisome, while Œ±-ketoglutarate is translocated from peroxisome
to chloroplast.
D. The action of enzyme serine hydroxymethyl transferase takes place in peroxisome.
Which one of the following combinations has all correct statements?
1. A and B

2. A and C

3. B and C

4. B and D

Answer 2
A. During photorespiration, the conversion of glycolate to glycerate in peroxisomes requires reducing equivalents (e.g., from
ferredoxin) and ATP. C. Glutamate is translocated from chloroplasts to peroxisomes during photorespiration, and Œ±-ketoglutarate is
translocated back from peroxisomes to chloroplasts.
Source: Fundamental and Practice, Life Sciences ‚Äì 1

Question No. 1 / Question ID 703205 | Shift - 2
Which of the following equations represents the graph shown?

1. log y = (log x) - 1
2. log y= (log x)/2 - 1
3. log y= (log x) - log(1)
4. log y= (log x)/2 + 1
Answer: 2
Here is straight line plot between log y versus log x, with intercept on the Y-axis at -1
Y = mx + c
Where, c = intercept on the Y-axis = -1
Slope (m) = ‚àÜùëåùëå/‚àÜùëãùëã = (0‚Äì(-1)) / (2-0) = ¬Ω
Therefore, the equation takes the form as shown in option 2

Question No. 2 / Question ID 703203 | Shift - 2
Starting at the same time policewomen A and B chase thief T. They all run in the same direction at constant
speeds. A runs twice as fast and B thrice as fast as T. If A and B catch up with T at the same time, B must have
started
1. half as far behind T as A did
2. 1¬Ω times as far behind T as A did
3. twice as far behind T as A did
4. 3 times as far behind T as A did
Answer: 3
Let the speed of the thief be x Kmph
Speed of A 2x Kmph
Speed of B 3x kmph
B
A
T
d Km
2d Km

Because they all reach at the same time

3d Km

Difference between A and T = 2d ‚Äì d = d Km
Difference between B and T = 3d ‚Äì d = 2d Km

Question No. 3 / Question ID 703208 | Shift - 2
Among A, B, C and D, one is a doctor, one is a teacher, one is an engineer, and the other is a lawyer. The teacher
is older to B but younger than D. B is older to the doctor and younger than C. Which among the following is a
conclusive inference?
1. A is the engineer
2. B is the lawyer
3. C is the teacher
4. D is not the doctor

Answer: 4
According to the first statement: B is younger than D
According to the second statement: B is older to the Doctor
Hence, choice 4 is correct D is not the doctor

Question No. 4 / Question ID 703210 | Shift - 2
Two circles of radii 9.0 units and 4.0 units touch each other externally as in the figure. Then the length (in units)
of their common tangent AB is
1. 6‚úì3

2.

3. 12

4.

13

12 ‚úì2

Answer: 3
Solution: Let the two circles with centers A and B and radii 4 cm and 9 cm respectively touch each other
externally at a point C.
Then, AB = AC + CB = (4 + 9) cm = 13 cm.
Let PQ be a direct common tangent to the two circles.
Join AP and BQ. Then, AP‚ä• PQ and BQ ‚ä• PQ.
[Radius through point of contact is perpendicular to the tangent]
Draw, BL ‚ä• AP. Then, PLBQ is a rectangle.
Now, LP = BQ = 4 cm and PQ = BL.
AL = (AP - LP) = (9 ‚Äì 4) cm = 5 cm.
From right triangle ALB, we have
AB2 = AL2 + BL2‚áí BL2 = AB2 ‚àí AL2 = (13) 2‚àí(5) 2 = 169 ‚Äì 25 = 144
‚áíBL = ‚àö144 = 12 cm.
PQ = BL = 12 cm.
Hence, the length of direct common tangent is 12 cm.
Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 5 / Question ID 703206 | Shift - 2
Incomes (in lakhs) of two persons A and B, over the years 2006- 2010 are shown in the graph.

Which of the following statements is true?
1. Over the years, trends of income of A and B are the same.
2. The largest difference in incomes of A and B is in the year 2008.
3. During the given period, the average income of A is higher by 1.8 lakh compared to B.
4. During the given period, the annual income of A was below its average more than twice.
Answer: 4
Number of years = 5
Average income of A = (6+5+4+5+6)/5 =26/5 = 5.2 lakhs
Average income of B = (3+4+2+4+5)/5 =18/5 = 3.6 lakhs
Now if we tally the graph, we can see annual income of A was below its average more than twice (three times).
Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 6 / Question ID 703209 | Shift - 2
Four villages form the vertices of a rectangle of dimensions 8.0 km x 6.0 km. Roads are to be laid connecting
the villages such that the distance by road between each pair of villages is the same. The shortest such road
distance (in km) between any pair of villages will be
1. 10

2. 10 ‚úì3
3. 10 ‚úì2
4. 14

Answer: 1
The shortest distance between any random two villages will be the hypotenuse, which are diagonals in a
rectangle. Applying Pythagoras theorem to calculate the length of the hypotenuse we get:
Diagonal2 = Length2 + Width2 ‚áí (8)2+(6) 2 = 64 + 36 = 100
‚áí Diagonal =‚àö100 = 10 cm.

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 7 / Question ID 703211 | Shift - 2
The production of goods in a factory over 9 months is shown in the graph.

The average growth (in tons per month) over the period under consideration
1. is 0.3

2.

is 0.4

3. varies between -0.2 and +0.5

4.

varies between +0.2 and +0.5

Answer: 1
Individually compare the growth between subsequent months by subtracting the production in the current
month with the previous month and then take the average, i.e.:
(3-2.6)+(3.3-3)+(3.5-3.3)+ (3.8-3.5)+ (4.2-3.8)+ (4-4.2)+ (4.5-4)+ (5-4.5)/8 = 0.3
Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 8 / Question ID 703217 | Shift - 2
100 ml of alcohol from container A containing 1 L of alcohol is transferred to another container B containing 1 L of water and
mixed well. From this, 100 ml is transferred back to container A. The amount of alcohol in container B would be
1.

the same as the amount of water in container A

2.

more than the amount of water in container A

3.

less than the amount of water in container A

4.

indeterminable

Answer: 1
Solution:
There are two containers A and B.
A contains 1L of alcohol.
B contains 1L of water.
100 ml of alcohol from X is transferred to Y.
Now, we get,
A ‚Üí alcohol = 900 ml
B ‚Üí alcohol = 100 ml and Water = 1000 ml
Total mixture in B is 1100 ml in which ratio of Alcohol and Water is 1:11 respectively.
After that 100 ml of the mixture of B is transferred to A,
Mixture to be transferred from B = B ‚Üí alcohol = 100/12, Water = (100/12) x 11 = 1100/12
Remaining mixture in B = B ‚Üí alcohol = 100 - (100/12) = 1100/12, Water = 100 - (1100/12) = 100/12
New Mixture in A = A ‚Üí Alcohol = 900+ (100/12) = 10900/12, Water = 100/12
the proportion of water in A i.e. 100/12
the proportion of alcohol in B i.e. 100/12
It means the amount of alcohol in container B would be same as the amount of water in container A
Pathfinder Academy

Offline and Online CSIR-NET | CUET-PG | GATE | IIT-JAM | ICMR | GAT-B | 9818063394

Question No. 9 / Question ID 703202 | Shift - 2
Angela travels from town A to town T, 10 km away. When she's halfway, Betty starts from town B for T, 15 km
away. When Betty is half way, Charlie starts from town C for T, 30 km away. When he's half way, Dave starts
from town D for T, 40 km away. If their speeds are uniform and in the ratio 1 :3:12:16, respectively, the last one
to reach T will be
1. Angela
2. Betty
3. Charlie
4. Dave
Answer: 4
Let us assume Angela‚Äôs speed 1 kmph.
Then speed of Betty, Charlie and Dave are 3, 12 and 16 kmph
By the time Betty starts distances covered by Angela = 5 km
By the time Charlie starts distances covered by Betty is 7.5 km in 2.5 hrs. And Angela have covered 7.5 Km in 7.5 hrs.
By the time Dave starts distances covered by Charlie is 20 km in 1.25 hrs
By the time Dave will complete the lap of 40 kms, others would have completed.

Question No. 10 / Question ID 703219 | Shift - 2
The following 15 observations are heights (in inches) of 15 persons
65, 61, 63, 65, 61, 61, 60, 60, 65, 85, 65, 86, 61, 65, 62
Which of the following is true?
1. Mean < Median < Mode
2. Median< Mode< Mean
3. Mode< Median< Mean
4. Median < Mean < Mode
Answer: 2
Mean will be (65+61+63+65+61+61+60+60+65+85+65+86+61+65+62)/15 = 65.66
Median is calculated after arranging the values in ascending order and taking the middle term, which is 63
Mode is the term which is most frequent 65

Question No. 13 / Question ID 703220 | Shift - 2
One letter is picked at random from each of the words LUNAR and LANDER.
The chance that the letters picked from both words belong to the word PRAGYAN is
1. 3/10

2. 3/7

3. 1/2

4. 7/10

Answer: 1
From LUNAR there are 3 letters which are common, while that from LANDER there are again 3 letters.
Successful event is the one where the letters picked from both words belong to the word PRAGYAN, the chance
is: 3/5 x 3/6 = 3/10

Question No. 14 / Question ID 703212 | Shift - 2
A large rectangular paper having sides in the ratio of 3:8 is cut in half across the longer side. The process is
repeated several times. At which stages of the repeated cuttings will the ratio of the sides be 3:8?
1. Never
2. Every second cut
3. Every third cut
4. Every fifth cut

Answer: 1
Paper is folded in half across the longer side.
Original ratio = 3/8
3/8ÔÉ†3/4ÔÉ†3/2ÔÉ†1.5/2 ÔÉ† if we keep on going we see that the ratio again is not attained at second, third or fifth cut.

Question No. 15 / Question ID 703201 | Shift - 2
Which one of the following represents the most precise measurement of a length?
1. 2.15 meter
2. 215 centimeter
3. 21.5 decimeter
4. 2.150 meter

Answer: 4
The most precise measurement of length is typically the one with the greatest number of significant figures. In this
case, the measurement with the most significant figures is: 2.150 meters
This measurement has four significant figures, indicating a higher level of precision compared to the other options.

Question No. 16 / Question ID 703218 | Shift - 2

1. 2 ‚Äì œÄ/4
2. 2 ‚Äì œÄ/3

2 units

3. 3 ‚Äì œÄ/2
4. 3 ‚Äì œÄ/4
Answer: 3
Side of the square 2 units (Given)
So, the area of the given square is 4 sq. unit
Now, we divide the large square into 4 equal squares. (Fig. l)
Each small square has the area 1 sq. unit
As we need the area of the shaded region we can remove the unshaded region which does not
contain shaded area (fig.ll)
Area of the new shape is 3 sq unit(fig.ll)
The area of shaded region is 3 ‚Äì (area of 2 quadrants (a and b))
‚áí 3 - œÄr2/2 ( r = side of the small square = 1 unit)
‚áí 3 - œÄ/2

Question No. 19 / Question ID 703213 | Shift - 2
Let 2a3b5c = 1200 where a, b, care integers. Then a+ 2b + 3c is
1. 7

2. 8

3. 11

4. 12

Answer: 4
The number 1200 can be broken down to prime factors in following manner:
243152 = 1200 i.e. a=4, b=1, c=2
Then a+ 2b + 3c = 4 + 2 x 1 + 3 x 2 = 12
